articles.headline: Protests Erupt in Hong Kong, Overshadowing China’s National Day Parade
articles.snippet: The contrast of National Day pageantry in Beijing versus anti-government mayhem in Hong Kong was almost certainly infuriating to President Xi Jinping.
articles.abstract: The contrast of National Day pageantry in Beijing versus anti-government mayhem in Hong Kong was almost certainly infuriating to President Xi Jinping.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s authoritarian president used the 70th anniversary of Communist Party rule on Tuesday to pledge that nothing would stop his nation’s ascent. But the message was marred by some of the worst anti-government violence to convulse Hong Kong, including the first police shooting of a protester.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley, Mike Ives and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: As Impeachment Fights Begin, Administration and Congress Clash Over Deposition
articles.snippet: House investigators postponed their first impeachment deposition amid a bitter back-and-forth with the secretary of state over access and transparency.
articles.abstract: House investigators postponed their first impeachment deposition amid a bitter back-and-forth with the secretary of state over access and transparency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration clashed on Tuesday with leaders of the House impeachment inquiry over their demands to question State Department officials who might have witnessed President Trump’s efforts to pressure Ukraine for political advantage.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Lara Jakes

articles.headline: Harvard Does Not Discriminate Against Asian-Americans in Admissions, Judge Rules
articles.snippet: The lawsuit presented one of the biggest challenges to affirmative action in years, and is almost certain to reach the Supreme Court.
articles.abstract: The lawsuit presented one of the biggest challenges to affirmative action in years, and is almost certain to reach the Supreme Court.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Tuesday rejected claims that Harvard had intentionally discriminated against Asian-American applicants, in a closely watched case that presented one of the biggest legal challenges to affirmative action in years.

articles.headline: Shoot Migrants’ Legs, Build Alligator Moat: Behind Trump’s Ideas for Border
articles.snippet: Over a frenzied few days in the spring, an internal White House debate led to turnover in staff and a turning point for the president’s immigration agenda.
articles.abstract: Over a frenzied few days in the spring, an internal White House debate led to turnover in staff and a turning point for the president’s immigration agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Oval Office meeting this past March began, as so many had, with President Trump fuming about migrants. But this time he had a solution. As White House advisers listened astonished, he ordered them to shut down the entire 2,000-mile border with Mexico — by noon the next day.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: Low-Cost Investing Can’t Get Any Lower Than Free
articles.snippet: Charles Schwab is eliminating fees for trades of stocks and exchange-traded funds. The move is part of a trend that has made it cheaper than ever to invest.
articles.abstract: Charles Schwab is eliminating fees for trades of stocks and exchange-traded funds. The move is part of a trend that has made it cheaper than ever to invest.
articles.lead_paragraph: Charles Schwab said Tuesday that it would allow customers to trade stocks and exchange-traded funds for free, ramping up the intensity of brokers’ fight for the average investor’s dollars.

articles.headline: Congress and Trump Agreed They Want a National Privacy Law. It Is Nowhere in Sight.
articles.snippet: Even amid a bipartisan backlash against tech companies, lawmakers have struggled to channel that into a federal privacy law.
articles.abstract: Even amid a bipartisan backlash against tech companies, lawmakers have struggled to channel that into a federal privacy law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A rare thing emerged in Washington early this year: agreement. Republicans and Democrats in Congress, as well as the Trump White House, all said they wanted a new federal law to protect people’s online privacy. Numerous tech companies urged them on.

articles.headline: Stocks Slide as Evidence Mounts of Slowdown Fueled by Trade War
articles.snippet: A recent wave of selling has ended a relatively calm stretch for stock markets.
articles.abstract: A recent wave of selling has ended a relatively calm stretch for stock markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: For much of the last year, America’s trade war was the rest of the world’s problem.
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips and Amie Tsang

articles.headline: Boeing 737 Max Safety System Was Vetoed, Engineer Says
articles.snippet: The company passed on the concerns to the Department of Justice as part of a criminal investigation into the engineering of the plane after two fatal crashes.
articles.abstract: The company passed on the concerns to the Department of Justice as part of a criminal investigation into the engineering of the plane after two fatal crashes.
articles.lead_paragraph: A senior Boeing engineer filed an internal ethics complaint this year saying that during the development of the 737 Max jet the company had rejected a safety system to minimize costs, equipment that he felt could have reduced risks that contributed to two fatal crashes.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff, David Gelles and Jack Nicas

articles.headline: U.S. to Tax European Aircraft, Agriculture and Other Goods
articles.snippet: The United States said it would impose tariffs after the World Trade Organization gave it permission to tax as much as $7.5 billion of European exports.
articles.abstract: The United States said it would impose tariffs after the World Trade Organization gave it permission to tax as much as $7.5 billion of European exports.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration said Wednesday that it would impose tariffs on European aircraft, French wine and cheese, Spanish olive oil and other goods starting Oct. 18, after the World Trade Organization granted the United States permission to tax as much as $7.5 billion of European exports annually.

articles.headline: ‘We’re Not Fooling Around’: House Democrats Vow to Subpoena White House
articles.snippet: President Trump angrily struck back at Democrats in sometimes profane terms, calling them “dishonest” and “corrupt” as they pursue impeachment.
articles.abstract: President Trump angrily struck back at Democrats in sometimes profane terms, calling them “dishonest” and “corrupt” as they pursue impeachment.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats moved on Wednesday to compel the White House to cooperate in their impeachment inquiry, announcing plans to issue a subpoena by Friday if it did not comply with requests for documents related to President Trump’s efforts to press Ukraine to investigate a leading political rival, and any attempt to conceal his actions.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders Is Hospitalized, Raising Questions About His Candidacy
articles.snippet: The Vermont senator had two stents inserted in an artery after experiencing chest discomfort at an event. His campaign canceled his events and said he would be resting for several days.
articles.abstract: The Vermont senator had two stents inserted in an artery after experiencing chest discomfort at an event. His campaign canceled his events and said he would be resting for several days.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders was recovering in a Las Vegas hospital on Wednesday after being treated for blockage of an artery, forcing him to cancel his events in the coming days and casting uncertainty over a candidacy already struggling to win new voters.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: China’s Spenders Are Saving. That’s a Problem for Everyone.
articles.snippet: Chinese consumers, a $4.9 trillion force, transformed the global economy. With their own economy slowing, they are pulling back.
articles.abstract: Chinese consumers, a $4.9 trillion force, transformed the global economy. With their own economy slowing, they are pulling back.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZHENGZHOU, China — Forty years after China began its near-miraculous run as the world’s most powerful economic growth engine, its people are experiencing something new and unsettling: a feeling that the best times may be behind them.
